body: @javasoze we can get this in the 0.9.1 release if you can update the javadoc
@gianm I'll tag it for 0.9.2 for now. Hopefully I can bang around the distribution stuff a bit after 0.9.1 is qualified.

Anyone who REALLY REALLY wants to use this NOW can use https://github.com/metamx/druid-cache-caffeine .

One of the advantages of being in druid proper is the built-in pacakging, so I'm ok if it is desired to be solved before merging.

@himanshug risk with this approach is that replicas can get out of sync due to different tasks interpreting rejection policies in different ways (clock drift for serverTime, message ordering differences across partitions for messageTime). If replicas are out of sync then that could cause three issues:
- Query result inconsistency in real-time, although this one is probably not too bad, as it would happen even without rejection. (Just due to different tasks being at different points in the stream)
- Query result inconsistency on historicals, due to segments in the same interval being out of sync. If an interval has more than maxRowsPerSegment rows, it will make more than one segment. It's possible that historicals will load a mix of segments from different kafka tasks. If they do this then due to the desync, things won't be lined up right.
- Potential task failure due to segment allocation sequences being out of sync. This can happen if one task allocates a segment for an old event but another task drops the event. In this case whichever task loses the race will fail its next allocation, if any, and then exit and be replaced.

These issues might not happen in a real deployment, and might be okay for the short term, but are something to be aware of‚Ä¶

@gianm agree with above, I had thought about 1 and 2 but I think 3rd is most problematic.
I'm OK dropping this feature and noting "kafka task and batch ingestion task conflict" as a known issue for 0.9.1 .

Hm, if just supporting messageTime is sufficient, it shouldn't be too difficult to do a per-partition messageTime rejection strategy that would produce identical segments across replicas without any complex coordination.
A few comments but overall looks great!

@gianm @dclim one option could be that supervisor would pass a "start_time" (same value to all replicas within a partition group, similar to sequenceId) and task would use |event_time - start_time| to decide whether to accept/reject a message. that would be deterministic.
that should work?

I think that should work as long as you're okay with it operating differently from how windowPeriod works now - for example, if you specify a windowPeriod of 10 minutes for a task that runs for 60 minutes, at the beginning of the task it would accept messages as long as they are less than 10 minutes old but by the end it would accept messages up to 70 minutes old. So it's not really serverTime, or messageTime, but something like a taskStartTime rejection policy.

yes, that is true. but , that is ok, usecase here is not really that of window period as in the current realtime task but that of ensuring that events older than certain window are ignored to ensure that kafka task would never try to allocate segments beyond a known time window in the past.

@bohemia420  - In my case, I noticed the exception has nothing to do with the underlying issue. It was simply a mis-configured spec in my case.
Kickass! Thank you for incorporating my comments!

@gianm I'm not quite sure what benchmarks you want so I'll give you the information I have:

Local cache (current Druid local impl) simply does not work on our hot historical nodes in production. Query times become horrid (many seconds) under peak load.

Local cache seems to do fine in our metrics cluster. (not as high of peak load)

Caffeine does fine overall, but in prod-hot requires significant GC tuning, but is much better than either memcached only or the current local cache.

@himanshug Yes, for that use case that seems like a reasonable solution to implement and as far as I can tell would produce correct results across replicas. I'm not sure if you've started implementing the proposed solution or not but I can take a look at it if you haven't started. Instead of passing both a "start time" and a "window period" to the task, I'm thinking of just having the supervisor pass a single minimumMessageTime or something to that effect that'll be calculated by the supervisor based on it's now time + a period specified in the spec. @gianm thoughts?

@dclim that sounds good to me. The only potential issue I can think of is replicas having different minimumMessageTimes. Is there going to be any issue with replica-replacement causing failed tasks to be replaced with ones that have a different minimumMessageTime? Even if the replicas are created by a different supervisor than the one that made the original tasks?

@drcrallen I believe you that it's better. I was mostly hoping for a reproducible load test that shows how much better this under concurrent load than the old local cache. But I wouldn't insist on that for getting the extension in, since your experience in production makes it clear that it is an improvement.
@dclim i haven't started on that, feel free to send the PR if you want and close this one.

@gianm yeah I was thinking about that too as the main complication - the supervisor would select a minimumMessageTime when it creates a taskGroup (the set of tasks processing the same partitions/starting from the same offset) and would apply that same value to all future tasks created in that taskGroup (such as if some failed and had to be replaced). New supervisors would have to read this value from any currently running tasks when the supervisor starts up and initialize the taskGroup with it. If it finds a task with one minimumMessageTime and then discovers another one with the same partitions/starting offsets with a different one, that should be an illegal state and it should kill one of them.
@himanshug okay I can take a look at it in a bit
@dclim does that mean the minimumMessageTime would be incorporated into the sequence name?

Re 1: "walk through the sequence, gather the keys, do a bulk lookup in order to build a lookup map locally, then build a new sequence out of the old sequence using the lookup map" will require either materializing the sequence or computing it twice (two sets of queries to data nodes). Materializing will negate the broker's ability to stream back results so I think we should avoid that. Better approach might be to materialize the sequence in batches (like 1000 or 10000 rows at a time) and then do bulk lookups for keys in each batch.

@gianm hm, it could be, or it could be omitted and handled separately if that's easier; I believe the supervisor currently uses part of the sequence name to determine task 'equality' - i.e. rather than comparing all the properties in the Kafka index task spec, it just uses the hash of the spec that's calculated for the sequence name.. so having this hash include minimumMessageTime might complicate things when a new supervisor starts up and checks to see if there are any tasks it should care about.. I'll take a look and see what's easier, unless there are other considerations of why it should or should not be incorporated into the sequence name.
@dclim I was thinking that it being part of the 'equality' is actually good, because two tasks with different minimumMessageTimes are not going to create the same segments are are not equal.
If there is some other way of making sure things work out, though, then that's okay too.

@kaijianding: Not a blocker for this PR, just out of curiousity, did you ran any benchmarks with rollup disabled ? 
would be great to see performance comparison for ingestion, persisting & merging with and without rollup. you can probably use IndexMargeBenchmark & OnheapIncrementalIndexBenchmark.
I _think_ #2738 fixed this.
:+1:, If possible would be nice to modify S3DataSegmentMoverTest to catch this case.

I believe you are correct. The original intention was to always have a pattern matching for the lookup specification, as such the uri base specified had things after the final '/' pretty much not treated how the user expected. The addition in #2738 was to account for the common case of exact file names rather than pattern matching.
@nishantmonu51 added
@drcrallen, thanks for confirming.

@gianm @himanshug implemented as discussed in #3029; if you have time to review this in the near future we can include it in 0.9.1 - I think the changes are pretty straightforward (and yes I did end up including the minimumMessageTime as part of the sequenceName).

The realtime nodes periodically polls (1 minute interval by default) the coordinator for segment handoff and when it completes, it should drop the segment, there is also a possibility that the realtime node is running some long running query which may also be  preventing the segment from being dropped.
was the realtime node eventually able to drop the segment eventually or the realtime node kept it loaded forever ? would you be able to share complete logs for coordinator and realtime node for this duration ?
:+1:, If possible, would be nice to extend MainTest to verify it.

@sascha-coenen No.

We've never really considered Arrow, however the issue that once completed will eventually lead to Druid supporting extendable segment formats including Arrow is here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2965

During testing in the real server cluster, I experienced library dependency problem.

maven dependency updated

To minimize some the GC overhead you might benefit from an off-heap cache. That's because you are always serializing/deserializing anyways. Most off-heap caches are pretty slow by having coarse locks, but you might be able to layer it with Caffeine to reduce the penalty. The on-heap (Caffeine) cache would be moderately sized and the off-heap would be inclusive (to avoid response time skews caused by evictions). That might give you the regular performance of Caffeine, with the GC friendliness of [OHC](https://github.com/snazy/ohc). [Apache Mnemonic](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mnemonic) would let Caffeine cheaply become off-heap, but I think its too immature.

It would be nice if you have a way to avoid the byte[] churn, such as using a threadlocal buffer. Netty might have [good stuff](https://blog.twitter.com/2013/netty-4-at-twitter-reduced-gc-overhead) here.

The other approach might be to use off-heap values instead of the byte[]. That would let you reduce GC while not losing the benefit of the scan resistant eviction policy (TinyLFU). Allocating segments from an on-heap byte[](e.g. slab allocator) like Netty provides has pretty much the same effect as off-heap, but doesn't require any Unsafe magic. So there is potential to reduce your GC churn without significant effort.

It sounds like we can close this in favor of #3035, @himanshug please reopen if desired.

@ben-manes with how the druid cache is constructed, any multi-layered cache can be used via https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/server/src/main/java/io/druid/client/cache/HybridCache.java 

The graphs at the master comment are from using this approach to fast-cache to caffeine, and slow-cache to memcached.

Perhaps the compression should be moved up one level, as each cache implementation is compressing independently (e.g.  `LZ4Transcoder`). This means for a L1 miss it perform an unnecessary serialization. For a `put` it serializes twice. You mentioned previously the L1 hit rate could be as low as 20%, so 4:5 requests do extra work.

@drcrallen this is for an emitter extension I'm working on, the binding would be used to attach a "nodeType" field to the events sent out by the emitter
@nishantmonu51 added a nodeType check to MainTest

@fjy I added these notes from issues marked "release notes"
- The default value for maxRowsInMemory has been set to 75,000 across the board for all forms of ingestion. This is in line with previous defaults for Hadoop tasks and Tranquility-based ingestion. If you were creating realtime index tasks directly (without Tranquility) then this is lower than the previous default of 500,000.
- The `/druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}?kill=true&interval={myISO8601Interval}` REST endpoint is now deprecated. The new `/druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}/intervals/{interval}?kill=true` REST endpoint can be used instead.
- druid.indexer.runner.separateIngestionEndpoint is now deprecated. If you were using this functionality to isolate event-push requests and query serving requests for realtime tasks, you can accomplish something similar with druid.indexer.server.maxChatRequests.
- For developers of Druid extensions, note that the QueryGranularity constants (ALL, NONE, etc) have been moved to io.druid.granularity.QueryGranularities in #2980. Query syntax is not affected.
added a short blurb on the Kafka indexing service

This would be great. I would advocate making the aggregates 'firstBy' and 'lastBy' so that you could do: `FIRST_BY(`revenue`, `__time`)` to get first by time or `FIRST_BY(`revenue`, `my_id`)` to get it by `my_id` there should also be a way to define the compare on `my_id` (lexiographic, alphanumeric) and maybe some other comparison options like how much space to allocate for string comparisons. 

Related to: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2989

Hi @ecesena, thanks for the contribution. Would you mind filling out the SLA at http://druid.io/community/cla.html ?

The issue here is that [io.druid.indexing.common.config.TaskConfig#DEFAULT_DEFAULT_HADOOP_COORDINATES](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/druid-0.9.1-rc1/indexing-service/src/main/java/io/druid/indexing/common/config/TaskConfig.java#L33) defines a version to use in the absence of some other version, and THAT version is supposed to be pulled unless [--no-default-hadoop](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/druid-0.9.1-rc1/services/src/main/java/io/druid/cli/PullDependencies.java#L156) is specified.
My bad, specifying `-h` implies `--no-default-hadoop`

since the default is `<hadoop.compile.version>2.3.0</hadoop.compile.version>`, I propose adding a warning comment in the pom at the version specification stating that modifying this value will cause the default hadoop coordinate to be invalid. Meaning that the user must specify the correct hadoop coordinate to use in their runtime.properties or task context

It seems likely that anyone modifying that hadoop compile version would also want to modify the default default hadoop version as well (just so tasks can work without having coordinate overrides). So in that case maybe all we need is the comment.
SLA signed
